verses.text: Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman he had married, for he had married a Cushite woman.
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes Moses' marriage to a Cushite (Ethiopian) woman; original wording preserved.

verses.text: And they said, "Has the LORD indeed spoken only through Moses? Has he not also spoken through us?" And the LORD heard it.
verses.comment: Direct quote maintained for clarity; minor smoothing for modern readability.

verses.text: Now the man Moses was very humble, more than any man on the face of the earth.
verses.comment: Alternate translations may use 'meek' for 'humble'; 'humble' is chosen for clarity.

verses.text: And the LORD suddenly said to Moses and to Aaron and to Miriam, "Come out, you three, to the Tent of Meeting." And the three of them came out.
verses.comment: Phrase 'suddenly said' retains sense of immediacy from the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then the LORD came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance of the tent, and he called Aaron and Miriam, and they both came forward.
verses.comment: 'Pillar of cloud' and theophany language closely matched to Hebrew.

verses.text: And he said, "Hear my words: If there is a prophet among you, I, the LORD, make myself known to him in a vision; I speak with him in a dream.
verses.comment: 'Hear my words' is direct; order of clauses mirrors original.

verses.text: Not so with my servant Moses; he is faithful in all my house.
verses.comment: The phrase 'in all my house' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: With him I speak face to face, clearly, and not in riddles, and he beholds the form of the LORD. Why then were you not afraid to speak against my servant Moses?
verses.comment: Retains 'face to face' and 'form of the LORD' for accuracy.

verses.text: So the anger of the LORD was kindled against them, and he departed.
When the cloud went away from above the tent, behold, Miriam was leprous, white as snow. And Aaron turned toward Miriam, and behold, she was leprous.
verses.comment: 'Leprous, white as snow' follows the Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: And Aaron said to Moses, "Oh, my lord, please do not lay this sin on us, in which we have done foolishly and in which we have sinned.
Do not let her be as one dead, whose flesh is half consumed when he comes out of his mother's womb."
verses.comment: 'Half consumed' reflects metaphor in the original Hebrew.

verses.text: And Moses cried out to the LORD, "O God, please heal her—please!"
verses.comment: 'Please heal her—please!' translates the emphatic Hebrew particle na.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses, "If her father had but spit in her face, would she not be shamed for seven days? Let her be shut outside the camp seven days, and after that she may be brought in again."
verses.comment: Image of spitting and ritual exclusion is preserved.

verses.text: So Miriam was shut outside the camp seven days, and the people did not set out until Miriam was brought in again.
After that, the people moved from Hazeroth and camped in the wilderness of Paran.
